In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

In Julia, you can write a function `wrap_string` that wraps text at a specified width by iterating over the characters in the string and appending words to a new line when the current line length exceeds the maximum allowed width. Here's how you can define such a function:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int = 10)
    lines = String[]
    current_line = ""
    for word in split(text)
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line)
            current_line = ""
        end
        current_line *= " " * word
    end
    if length(current_line) > 0
        push!(lines, current_line)
    end
    return join(lines, "\n")
end
```

This function splits the text into words using `split` and then iterates over each word. It appends each word to a new line if adding the word to the current line would exceed the specified width. If the word fits within the remaining space of the current line, it is added without starting a new line.

To use this function, you can pass in a string and an optional `text_width` parameter:

```julia
julia> wrap_string("Hello there! This is a very long sentence that I want to wrap at 10 characters per line.")
"Hello there!\nThis is a very\nlong sentence\nthat I want\nto wrap at 10\ncharacters per line."
```

In this example, the text is wrapped at 10 characters per line as specified by the `text_width` parameter.
